parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several studies have examined the effects of using fences to exclude livestock from shrublands.
[Statement 2]: The results of studies examining the effects of using fences to exclude livestock from shrublands have varied across different countries.
[Statement 3]: In the UK, studies found that fencing increased shrub cover or abundance.
[Statement 4]: Studies in Germany and the UK indicated that fencing increased shrub biomass.
[Statement 5]: Studies in Germany and the UK indicated that fencing increased the biomass and height of individual heather plants.
[Statement 6]: In Denmark and the UK, controlled studies revealed that heather presence or cover was higher in fenced areas.
[Statement 7]: Not all studies on the effects of using fences have shown positive outcomes.
[Statement 8]: A site comparison study in the USA found that using fences led to a decrease in the cover of woody plants.
[Statement 9]: Studies in the USA and the UK reported that fencing had a mixed effect on shrub cover.
[Statement 10]: Studies in the USA and the UK reported that fencing did not alter shrub cover at all.
[Statement 11]: A study in the UK discovered that fencing did not change the number of plant species.
[Statement 12]: A study in the UK discovered that fencing did lead to an increase in vegetation height and biomass.
[Statement 13]: A controlled, before-and-after study in the UK found that fenced areas had lower species richness than unfenced areas.
[Statement 14]: The impact of fencing on grass cover has varied.
[Statement 15]: One trial in the UK and a study in the USA showed a decline in grass cover in fenced areas.
[Statement 16]: Four controlled studies in the USA, UK, and Finland found no change in grass cover in fenced areas.
[Statement 17]: One site comparison study in the USA and one replicated, controlled study in the UK recorded an increase in grass cover.
[Statement 18]: A controlled study in Finland found no change in herb species abundance due to fencing.
[Statement 19]: A site comparison in the USA showed no difference in forb cover between fenced and unfenced areas.
[Statement 20]: One controlled study in the USA that focused on excluding deer with fences found an increase in the height of shrubs.
[Statement 21]: One controlled study in the USA that focused on excluding deer with fences did not find an increase in shrub cover.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__Does the effectiveness of using fences to exclude livestock from shrublands vary between different countries?
_gemini-2-5-pro__To reduce the impacts of nitrogen pollution in UK heathlands, is prescribed burning more effective than mowing?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A randomized, replicated, controlled study in the UK found that prescribed burning to reduce the impact of nitrogen deposition did not alter the shoot length of common heather compared to mowing.
[Statement 2]: A randomized, replicated, controlled study in the UK found that prescribed burning to reduce the impact of nitrogen deposition did not alter the number of purple moor grass seedlings compared to mowing.
[Statement 3]: A controlled study in the UK found that burning to reduce the concentration of pollutants in a heathland affected by nitrogen pollution did not alter the cover of heather relative to areas that were mowed.
[Statement 4]: A controlled study in the UK found that burning to reduce the concentration of pollutants in a heathland affected by nitrogen pollution did not alter the shoot length of heather relative to areas that were mowed.

[Statement 1]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of creating buffer zones beside roads and other transportation corridors on shrublands.
[Statement 2]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of planting vegetation to act as a buffer to exclude pollution on shrublands.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What is the evidence for the effectiveness of creating corridors or buffer zones to mitigate the impacts of roads on shrublands?
_gemini-2-5-pro__What are the most beneficial interventions for restoring shrubland vegetation after a fire?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Allowing shrubland to regenerate without active management after a fire has been found in multiple trials to increase shrub cover or biomass.
[Statement 2]: One study found that sites allowed to recover without active restoration had similar shrub cover to unburned areas.
[Statement 3]: Allowing shrubland to regenerate without active management after a fire can result in increased heather height.
[Statement 4]: Allowing shrubland to regenerate without active management after a fire can result in increased cover of woody plant species.
[Statement 5]: Allowing shrubland to regenerate without active management after a fire can result in an increased height of three protea species.
[Statement 6]: One trial found no increase in shrub cover when shrubland was allowed to regenerate without active management.
[Statement 7]: While allowing shrubland to regenerate without active management can increase vegetation cover, the number of plant species may not increase.
[Statement 8]: In some cases of allowing shrubland to regenerate without active management, only a minority of plant species increased.
[Statement 9]: Allowing shrubland to regenerate without active management has been found to lead to a decrease in grass or herbaceous cover in some instances.
[Statement 10]: Using prescribed burning to control grass was found in one study not to reduce the target grass species' cover.
[Statement 11]: Using prescribed burning to control grass was found in one study to reduce the cover of common heather.
[Statement 12]: A study on prescribed burning showed an initial reduction in vegetation height, which recovered over time.

[Statement 1]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of placing signs to discourage access to sensitive areas of shrub habitat on shrublands.
[Statement 2]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of placing signs to deter the gathering of shrubland species.
[Statement 3]: No evidence was found for the effects of using signs and access restrictions to reduce disturbance on amphibian populations.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What is the state of the evidence for using signs or barriers to reduce human impacts like gathering or disturbance in shrublands?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Planting turf from intact heathland sites has been found to increase the abundance or cover of heathland species.
[Statement 2]: One study found that planting turf increased forb cover.
[Statement 3]: One study found that planting turf reduced grass cover.
[Statement 4]: In one study, planting large turves from intact heathland increased the number of plant species.
[Statement 5]: In one study, planting smaller turves from intact heathland did not increase the number of plant species.
[Statement 6]: A study in the USA found that combining the planting of California sagebrush with the sowing of seeds did not increase native plant cover compared to just sowing or just planting.
[Statement 7]: Removing topsoil or turf before seeding or planting has been found to increase plant community similarity to the target ecosystem.
[Statement 8]: Removing topsoil or turf before seeding or planting has been found to increase plant species richness.
[Statement 9]: Removing topsoil or turf before seeding or planting has been found to increase seedling survival.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__When restoring shrubland vegetation, what are the comparative effects of sowing seeds versus planting turf?
_gemini-2-5-pro__What interventions are available for controlling trees in South African shrublands, and what does the evidence say about their effects on overall plant communities?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A study in South Africa found that using herbicide to control trees increased plant diversity.
[Statement 2]: A study in South Africa found that using herbicide to control trees did not increase shrub cover.
[Statement 3]: Interventions for controlling trees in shrubland areas include prescribed burning.
[Statement 4]: Interventions for controlling trees in shrubland areas include the restoration or creation of shrubland.
[Statement 5]: Supporting evidence for using prescribed burning and shrubland restoration for tree control did not include studies from South Africa.
[Statement 6]: A study in the UK found that herbicide treatment of trees increased the abundance of common heather seedlings.
[Statement 7]: In Italy, prescribed burning to control trees reduced the cover of common heather.
[Statement 8]: In Italy, prescribed burning to control trees increased the cover of purple moor grass.
[Statement 9]: A study in Italy found that prescribed burning to control trees had mixed effects on the basal area of trees.
[Statement 10]: A study in the USA found no change in the cover of two of three grass species after prescribed burning was used to control trees.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__How do the effects of using cutting or mowing to mimic grazing vary between studies in Italy and Spain?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A site comparison in Italy found that mowing increased heather cover.
[Statement 2]: A site comparison in Italy found that mowing increased grass cover.
[Statement 3]: A site comparison in Italy found that mowing reduced tree cover.
[Statement 4]: Two trials in Spain found that cutting to mimic grazing reduced heather cover.
[Statement 5]: One trial in Spain found that cutting increased the number of plant species.
[Statement 6]: Another trial in Spain found that an increase in the number of plant species from cutting only occurred in a minority of cases.
[Statement 7]: A separate trial in Spain reported that cutting increased grass cover.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__To restore degraded shrublands by reintroducing plants, which methods have been found to be most beneficial?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: In the restoration of degraded shrublands, planting turf from intact heathland sites has been shown to increase the abundance or cover of heathland species.
[Statement 2]: In the UK, planting turf from intact heathland sites was found to increase seedling abundance for a majority of heathland plant species.
[Statement 3]: In the UK, planting turf from intact heathland sites was found to increase forb cover.
[Statement 4]: In the UK, planting turf from intact heathland sites was found to reduce grass cover.
[Statement 5]: A study in Iceland indicated that using large turves from intact heathland could increase the number of plant species.
[Statement 6]: A study in Iceland indicated that smaller turves from intact heathland did not increase the number of plant species.
[Statement 7]: A US study found that temporary irrigation increased shrub cover.
[Statement 8]: A US study found that adding topsoil alongside seeding resulted in an increased biomass of grasses when compared to adding topsoil alone.
[Statement 9]: A US study found that adding topsoil alongside seeding resulted in a reduced biomass of forbs when compared to adding topsoil alone.

[Statement 1]: Amending soil with a mix of manure and inorganic fertilizers has been found to increase microbial biomass and activity.
[Statement 2]: Amending soil with a mix of manure and inorganic fertilizers can increase soil organic carbon.
[Statement 3]: A mixture of manure and inorganic fertilizers was more effective at reducing cracks in dry soil than inorganic fertilizers alone or no fertilizer.
[Statement 4]: Manure by itself was found to increase microbial biomass and organic carbon.
[Statement 5]: In a created wetland, amending plots with large amounts of compost resulted in larger birch saplings three years after planting.
[Statement 6]: In a created wetland, amending plots with large amounts of compost resulted in lower plant species richness and diversity three years after planting.
[Statement 7]: Applying a high rate of compost in one trial increased soil organic matter, microbial biomass, and fruit yield.
[Statement 8]: The addition of municipal compost can reduce soil loss and water runoff.
[Statement 9]: Amending soil with fresh plant material, such as crop remains and straw, has been associated with increased microbial biomass.
[Statement 10]: Amending soil with fresh plant material has been associated with higher soil organic carbon and improved soil structure.
[Statement 11]: The use of green manures has been shown to increase soil organic carbon and grain yields.
[Statement 12]: Amending the soil with non-chemical minerals and mineral wastes has been found to reduce nutrient loss and erosion.

_gemini-2-5-pro__When attempting to control problematic grass in UK shrublands, how does mowing compare to stripping turf?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A controlled study in the UK found that cutting and removing turf increased the number of heathland plants.
[Statement 2]: Another UK study found that mowing increased the number of heathland plants in one of two sites.
[Statement 3]: A study on turf stripping found that the presence of a small number of heathland plants increased.
[Statement 4]: The same study on turf stripping found that the presence of a small number of non-heathland plants decreased.
[Statement 5]: A study on mowing found that the presence of a small minority of heathland plants increased.
[Statement 6]: The study on mowing found that the presence of non-heathland plants did not change.
[Statement 7]: A replicated, controlled study in the UK found that the presence of heather was similar in areas where turf was cut and in areas that were mown or rotovated.
[Statement 8]: A replicated, controlled study in the UK found that cutting to control purple moor grass did not alter the cover of common heather.
[Statement 9]: Two randomized, replicated, controlled studies in the UK found that the removal of topsoil did not increase heather cover or the cover of heathland species.
[Statement 10]: One controlled study in the UK did find an increase in heather cover following the removal of topsoil.
[Statement 11]: Three replicated, controlled studies in the UK and the USA found that cutting to control grass did not alter the cover of common heather or shrub seedling abundance.
[Statement 12]: A replicated, controlled study in the UK found that the presence of wavy hair grass was similar in areas where turf was cut and those that were mown or rotovated.
[Statement 13]: A similar study found that mowing did not alter the abundance of wavy hair grass relative to rotovating or cutting turf.
[Statement 14]: A controlled study in the UK found that the removal of turf reduced the cover of wavy hair grass.
[Statement 15]: A UK study found that the removal of topsoil increased the cover of annual grasses.
[Statement 16]: The same UK study found that the removal of topsoil led to a decrease in the cover of perennial grasses.
[Statement 17]: Two randomized, controlled studies in the USA found that mowing reduced grass cover.
[Statement 18]: In one of the two US studies on mowing, the grass cover recovered over time.

[Statement 1]: A trial in Norway and a study in the UK found that cutting bracken increased the cover or biomass of heather.
[Statement 2]: Two studies in the UK found that cutting bracken did not increase heather cover or the abundance of heather seedlings.
[Statement 3]: In the UK, one study showed that cutting to control bracken increased the species richness of heathland plant species.
[Statement 4]: Another study in the UK found that cutting bracken did not alter species richness but did increase species diversity.
[Statement 5]: A UK-based study revealed that cutting bracken increased the cover of wavy hair-grass and sheepâ€™s fescue.
[Statement 6]: A separate controlled study in the UK found that cutting bracken did not result in an increase in the abundance of gorse or common cow-wheat.
[Statement 7]: A trial in Norway and two studies in the UK indicated that cutting bracken reduced its cover or biomass.
[Statement 8]: A study in the UK showed that cutting bracken had mixed effects on bracken cover.
[Statement 9]: A controlled study in the UK found that cutting bracken did not decrease the abundance of bracken.
[Statement 10]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of cutting and burning bracken on shrublands.

_gemini-2-5-pro__What is the state of the evidence regarding creating or maintaining habitat corridors to mitigate the effects of human development, transportation, or energy production in shrublands?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: There is no evidence to support creating or maintaining habitat corridors in developed areas to mitigate the effects of human development on shrublands.
[Statement 2]: There is no evidence to support creating or maintaining habitat corridors over or under roads and other transportation corridors to mitigate the effects of human development on shrublands.
[Statement 3]: There is no evidence to support creating or maintaining habitat corridors in areas of energy production or mining to mitigate the effects of human development on shrublands.
[Statement 4]: For the actions of creating habitat corridors in developed areas, transportation corridors, or energy production areas, no studies were found that evaluated the effects of these actions on shrublands.

[Statement 3]: The method of cutting silver birch trees and applying herbicide was found to reduce the cover of silver birch trees in a replicated, controlled UK study.
[Statement 4]: There were no studies found that assessed the effects of solely cutting or mowing to control trees in shrublands.

_gemini-2-5-pro__What management techniques have been evaluated for controlling bracken in shrublands, and what are their effects on heather?

parts.text:

[Statement 7]: A randomized, controlled, before-and-after trial in Norway found that the combination of cutting bracken and applying herbicide increased heather cover.
[Statement 8]: The methods of applying herbicide, cutting bracken, and a combination of both were found to reduce bracken biomass or cover in some studies.

[Statement 8]: The number of tree seedlings was higher after summer grazing compared to winter grazing.
[Statement 9]: Shortening the grazing period had varied effects on heather, bilberry, crowberry, and grass cover.
[Statement 10]: Grazing only in winter or summer did not affect heather or grass height when compared to year-round grazing.

[Statement 9]: A study in France indicated that ungrazed sites had a lower cover of non-ericaceous shrubs compared to grazed sites.
[Statement 10]: A study in the UK found that reducing grazing had mixed effects on shrub cover.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Five before-and-after trials in the USA, UK, and Norway found that allowing shrubland to recover after a fire without any active management increased shrub cover or biomass.

[Statement 6]: One controlled, before-and-after trial in the USA found no increase in shrub cover during recovery from fire.

[Statement 9]: The same UK study found that prescribed burning did reduce the cover of common heather.

[Statement 11]: The same UK study found that this reduced vegetation height recovered over time.
[Statement 12]: One randomized, controlled study in Italy found that prescribed burning to control trees reduced the cover of common heather.
[Statement 13]: The same study in Italy found that prescribed burning to control trees increased the cover of purple moor grass.
